JONATHAN AGNEW ON 50 YEARS OF TMS
Test Match Special is celebrating its 50th birthday this summer which is a marvellous achievement.


It is such a unique programme and it's more than just cricket commentary, it has grown into something different.


It's hopefully an intelligent debating forum where people can tell stories and have a laugh, but perhaps most importantly of all, listeners have always been able to enjoy direct contact with the show. 


This was the legacy of the late, great Brian Johnston.


He was the master of being able to make people think he was talking to listeners as individuals and hopefully that lives on. 


For all of us it's as close to a dream job as we could imagine. 


We are all too old and decrepit to still be playing professional cricket so this is without doubt the next best thing.


Our producer Peter Baxter retires at the end of the West Indies series after an amazing 34 years in the job.


His impact on the team has been enormous, he has set the tone for the programme and I will miss him terribly as he has been my colleague, friend and travelling companion for 17 years.


If I had to pick out my favourite moment working on TMS it would have to be the 2005 Ashes series.


More than anything though, and it sounds corny, I just enjoy every day as they are all so completely unpredictable.


And the start of the third Test between England and the West Indies certainly didn't disappoint.


England looked to be cruising, but suddenly found themselves struggling after the West Indies' bowlers finally found the right line.


The pitch at Old Trafford has become the fastest in the country, and as we saw last year against Pakistan, the pitch can be steepling and uneven.


I am very much looking forward to seeing Steve Harmison bowling on it and it will be fascinating to see whether the influence of new bowling consultant Allan Donald will have any effect.


Enjoy the action,


Aggers 


Jonathan Agnew is part of the Test Match Special team that is commentating on the third Test between England v West Indies at Old Trafford. You can listen to TMS on BBC Radio 4 198LW and on Five Live Sports Extra on digitial radio from 1045 BST
